intro: Carmichaelia australis var. alata, commonly known as the coastal kōhanga, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its slender, climbing stems and small, pea-like flowers. The plant typically grows in coastal and subalpine regions, where it thrives in well-drained soils and full sun. Its leaves are bipinnate, and it produces pods that contain lens-shaped seeds, which are dispersed by wind. This variety is notable for its adaptability to harsh environmental conditions.
